On 5 November 2010 22:17, William Wilson <fluffysheap@...> wrote:
>
> Better example would be this:
> http://members.cox.net/mathmistakes/glossary1.htm#Shooting
>
> Given enough data, it's possible to find correlations to practically anything, but that does not mean there is any predictive power.
>
> You might also be interested in/amused by:
> http://xkcd.com/552/
> http://xkcd.org/808/
>

Yup, am an xkcd reader :)

Yes I'll admit that finding correlations and assuming they have
predictive power is a far more common mistake. But I still stand by my
argument that just because astrology is nonsense doesn't mean it
wouldn't have actual predictive power - so long as enough people
believed in it and applied it. Of course on aggragte they will be
playing a zero sum game (no-one wins overall and transaction costs
mean the average player loses), and then smarter folks predict once
step ahead and then two steps, etc and the system decends back into
chaotic noise.

I think I just disproved my argument(*) :)

* - in the long run. This might still work over a given time period,
that is, until enough people catch on.

Colin.
